lines.text: The important thing is the rhythm. Always have rhythm in your shaking. Now a Manhattan you shake to fox-trot time, a Bronx to two-step time, a dry martini you always shake to waltz time.
Say listen, is he working on a case?
Yes, he is.
What case?
A case of scotch. Pitch in and help him.
I'm a hero. I was shot twice in the Tribune.
I read where you were shot 5 times in the tabloids.
It's not true. He didn't come anywhere near my tabloids.
You got a pistol permit?
No.
Ever heard of the Sullivan Act?
Oh, that's all right, we're married.
[On the motley group of guests present]
Oh, Nicky, I love you because you know such lovely people.
Waiter, will you serve the nuts? I mean, will you serve the guests the nuts?
Oh, it's all right, Joe. It's all right. It's my dog. And, uh, my wife.
Well you might have mentioned me first on the billing.
You know, that sounds like an interesting case. Why don't you take it?
I haven't the time. I'm much too busy seeing that you don't lose any of the money I married you for.
I don't like crooks. And if I did like 'em, I wouldn't like crooks that are stool pigeons. And if I did like crooks that are stool pigeons, I still wouldn't like you.
[the guests are finding their places to sit at the dinner table]
I'm Mrs. Jorgenson!
lines.character: Mimi Jorgenson, the former Mrs. Wynant

lines.text: Put it over there, sister. I was Mrs. Jorgenson before you were.
Take care of yourself
Why, sure I will.
Don't say it like that! Say it as if you meant it!
Well, I do believe the little woman cares.
I don't care! It's just that I'm used to you, that's all.
All right! Go ahead! Go on! See if I care! But I thinks it's a dirty trick to bring me all the way to New York just to make a widow of me.
You wouldn't be a widow long.
You bet I wouldn't!
Not with all your money...
Say, how did you people happen to pop in here?

We hear this is getting to be sort of a meeting place for the Wynant family, so we figured we'll stick around just in case the old boy himself should show up. Then we see this bird sneak in, we decide to come up. And lucky for you we did!
Yes, I might not have been shot.
Now my friends, if I may propose a little toast. Let us eat, drink and be merry, for tomorrow we die.
You give such charming parties, Mr. Charles.
Thank you, Mrs. Charles.
How many drinks have you had?
This will make six Martinis.

[to the waiter]
All right. Will you bring me five more Martinis, Leo? Line them right up here.
Well, can't you tell us anything about the case?
Yes, it's putting me way behind in my drinking.
What's that man doing in my drawers?
The murderer is right in this room. Sitting at this table. You may serve the fish.

[to Asta, as Nick and Asta are going out on a case]
If you let anything happen to him, you'll never wag that tail again.

[after the doorbell rings on Christmas Eve]
Who's that?
It's probably Santa Claus.

[carrying a tray of drinks]
Here's that man again! Ammunition! Highballs and cocktails - the long and short of it.
How'd you like Grant's tomb?
It's lovely. I'm having a copy made for you.
Pretty girl.
Yes. She's a very nice type.
You got types?
Only you, darling. Lanky brunettes with wicked jaws.
Nick? Nicky?
What?
You asleep?
Yes!
Good. I want to talk to you.
Say, I'm getting out of here.
No, you stay here.
If I stay, I know I'm gonna take a poke at him.
Then I insist that you stay.
Hey, would you mind putting that gun away? My wife doesn't care, but I'm a very timid fellow.
You idiot!

[to the gunman]
Alright, shoot! I mean, uh, what's on your mind?
Now how did you ever remember me?
Oh, you used to fascinate me. A real live detective. You used to tell me the most wonderful stories. Were they true?
Probably not.
[Nick has revived Nora after knocking her out to keep her from being accidentally shot by Joe Morelli]
You darn fool! You didn't have to knock me out. I knew you'd take him, but I wanted to see you do it.

[laughs]
There's a girl with hair on her chest.

[suffering from a hang-over]
What hit me?
The last martini.

[after Nick gets shot at]
Do you want a drink?
What do you think?
Is that my drink over there?
What were you drinking?
Rye.

[finishes her drink in one gulp and hands her the empty glass]
Yes, that's yours.
[first lines]
Your daughter's here, Mr. Wynant. Mr. Wynant! Mr. Wynant!
Haven't you got any more sense than to shout at me like that?
[last lines]
Nicky... Nicky, put Asta in here with me tonight.

[chuckles]
Oh, yeah?
[throws Asta in the other bunk]
Now don't make a move or that dog will tear you to shreds.
Could I come down and see the body? I've never seen a dead body.
Why do you want to?
Well, I've been studying psychopathic criminology and I have a theory. Perhaps this was the work of a sadist or a paranoiac. If I saw it I might be able to tell.
Yeah, that's a good idea. But don't you bother to come down - we'll bring the body right up to you.
What's the gag?
You know as much about it as I do.

[shouting]
Have a cocktail!
N-no, I don't care for any.

[Still shouting]
I said, have a cocktail!

[Nervously]
I guess he wants us to have a cocktail.

[Examining the over-sized clothes of a recently-discovered corpse]
He must've weighed 250 pounds if he weighed an ounce.

[Handing Guild a cane]
Here's something.
Hmmm. Rubber tip. He must have been lame.
Who wouldn't be, carrying all that weight around?

[inviting MacCaulay in]
What are you drinking?
Oh, nothing, thanks. Nothing.
Oh, that's a mistake.

[to telephone operator]
I want to speak to Ma!
Haven't you heard the news? I'm a gentleman now!
C'mon in kid, shed the chapeau.
It's the nicest dinner I ever listened to.
